channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-9390] groovysh 3.0.0 not working with jdk 11.0.6
item.description:
c:\>groovysh
java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException

item.environment:
Windows 10 and Linux
Groovy Version: 3.0.0 JVM: 11.0.6 Vendor: Oracle Corporation OS: Windows 10
java version "11.0.6" 2020-01-14 LTS
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11.0.6+8-LTS)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.6+8-LTS, mixed mode)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
As a workaround, you can try set JAVA_OPTS=--add-opens=java.base/jdk.internal.jrtfs=ALL-UNNAMED before running groovySh for now.

 

paulk Which JDK version was used to buid 3.0.0 binary distribution?

I used JDK 11.0.5 to buid binary distribution, which runs well on JDK 11.0.6.

https://scans.gradle.com/s/h25t4se4fqhra

 

C:\Users\Daniel.LAPTOP-H7RKNSIS>groovySh
Groovy Shell (3.0.0, JVM: 11.0.6)
Type ':help' or ':h' for help.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
groovy:000>

I tried to build the binary distribution from 3.0.0 source distribution with JDK 11.0.6

https://gradle.com/s/24k52qqzx2cgm

 
The groovySh of the newly built binary distribution runs well too:

C:\Users\Daniel.LAPTOP-H7RKNSIS>groovySh
Groovy Shell (3.0.0, JVM: 11.0.6)
Type ':help' or ':h' for help.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
groovy:000>

I guess the convenience binary distribution of 3.0.0 invokes

jdk.internal.jrtfs.JrtFileSystem#getPath

But the following method should be invoked:

java.nio.file.FileSystem#getPath

I find no Java9 vmplugin, i.e. Java9.class file is found in the convenience binary distribution, so it was probably not built with JDK 9+, thus Java9 vmplugin was excluded.

BTW, all illegal access warnings will come back if no Java9 vmplugin is available...

I don't know how it happened but I am seeing the same as you Daniel. I guess we should do a 3.0.1 soon to fix this. I'll see if I can make the release script abort not just print a warning if JDK8 is used.
Sorry about that. Should be fixed in the next point release.
